protocol.name: P-MTAB-4190
protocol.text: Plants were grown under standard greenhouse conditions.

protocol.name: P-MTAB-4191
protocol.text: Two Arabidopsis accessions (Ler and Cvi) and 17 Recombinant Inbred Lines (RILs) derived from them were subjected in 24 replicated populations to four levels of micro-landscape fragmentation and two levels of disturbance, factorially crossed with each other to yield 8 experimental selection regimes. We set up 24 experimental landscapes consisting of 2, 4, 8, or 16 patches where the total area was constrained to be equal. Plants that germinated outside the designated suitable patches were removed. In half of the landscapes – which we termed static – the top 2-3 mm of seeds and soil were removed from the surface of the suitable patches after 8 weeks of growth and reproduction. In the other half of the landscapes – which we termed dynamic – a number of Petri dishes, equivalent in size and number to the existing suitable patches, were distributed around the landscape at random, to catch dispersing seeds. The seeds collected by these two methods were cold-treated for one week while all patches were replenished with fresh substrate. Seeds were then returned to the surface of the new patches at the beginning of the next generation. Thus, in dynamic landscapes, seeds must disperse to have any chance of entering the next generation, while in static landscapes, only seeds that do not disperse have any chance of further propagation. After five generations of such selection, a single pod from approximately 70 individuals from each landscape was removed. Single individuals derived from such pods were reared under standardized conditions to measure several phenotypic characters, such as seed mass, height, presence of the erecta mutation, flowering time etc.

protocol.name: P-MTAB-4192
protocol.text: Flowers for DNA extraction from each population (? 50 plants/population) and leaves from the parental accessions Cvi and Ler, were collected for DNA extraction. The frozen material (-80C) was ground and  the resulting powder was used in the Qiagen DNA easy kit (#69104).  The DNA was re-suspended in 100ul water for labelling.

protocol.name: P-MTAB-4193
protocol.text: The Invitrogen BioPrime DNA labeling system (#18094-011) was used. The total labeling reaction volume is 150ul. To ~30ul (300ng) Plant DNA add 60ul 2.5X random primers, and make up to 132ul dH2O. Denature at > 95C for 5-10minutes, then cool on ice. Add 15ul 10X dNTPs mix with Biotin dCTP. Add 3ul Klenow polymerase enzyme. Incubate overnight @ 25C (room temp).  This results in small labeled products of about 50bp. Purify by sodium ethanol precipitation. Add 15ul 3M NaOAc, 400ul cold 100% Ethanol, spin, remove supernatant, and wash with 500ul cold  75% EtOH. Resuspend in 100ul water. Use 5ul to check yield and quality on a gel.  All bands should be close to the same intensity.  Dilute samples if necessary so that each reaction has the same amount of labeled product.

protocol.name: P-MTAB-4194
protocol.text: The labeled DNA is hybridized the same as labeled cRNA in standard hybridization protocols for gene expression to Affymetrix ATH1 Affymetrix GeneChips®. Mix 10ug of labeled DNA with 3.3ul Control Oligo B2 (3nM), 10ul Eukaryotic Hybridization Controls (optional), 2ul Herring Sperm DNA (10mg/ml), 2ul Acetylated BSA (50mg/ml), 110ul 2X hybridization buffer. Make up with dH2O to a Final Volume ~225ul. Heat Denature >95C for 5 minutes, then cool on ice.  After 10 minute pre-hybridization of arrays with 1X hybridization buffer at 45C, replace with 200ul denatured hybridization cocktail (above). Hybridize overnight @ 45C with rotation 60rpm. Use standard eukaryotic wash and double antibody stain.

protocol.name: image_acquisition
protocol.text: The Affymetrix Scanner 3000 7G with autoloader and standard protocol was used for scanning the Affymetrix ATH1 Affymetrix GeneChips®.

protocol.name: normalisation
text: Spatial correction was performed via a sliding square window of specified size which can reveal local array artifacts. The background was subtracted from the raw data on the log scale. Next, the arrays were quantile normalized so that they each had the same distribution. Analysis scripts for background correction and normalization are available here (

protocol.name: P-MTAB-4197
text: To identify single feature polymorphisms (SFPs) a matrix of spatially corrected normalized PM data which contains 8 columns (1 for each array) and 202882 rows (one for each feature) was created. The means and sum of squared deviations were calculated for each feature. The SAM d-statistic was calculated, which is similar to a t-statistic except that a constant (s0) was added to the denominator. This guards against large d-statistics for small mean differences between genotypes when the error is also small. To estimate the False Discovery Rate (FDR) the null distribution of the ordered d-statistic was determined. Labels on the 4 Cvi and 4 Ler arrays were shuffled as if the experiment was performed without keeping track of the genotypes. In each permutation, d-statistics were calculated for all features. 70 permutations were used to estimate the FDR. The d-statistics were sorted for each permutation and averaged to estimate the null distribution. The assumption here was that the ordered d-statistics for each feature come from the same ordered distribution. The FDR was then calculated at different thresholds by counting the number or ordered d-statistics greater than a threshold in both the original data and in each permuted data set. The average number of d-statistics that exceed a threshold among the permuted data sets was an estimate of the number of false positives. The false discovery rate was this number divided by the number of SFPs identified (d-statistics exceeding a threshold) in the original data and was chosen to be below 5% for identification of SFPs. Subsequently SFPs were used for bulk segregant analysis to identify allele frequency shifts between generations 1 and 5 of the experimental landscapes. The first step of bulk segregant mapping is to scale each SFP so that the difference between the two parental genotypes (Cvi and Ler) is 1 and the mean is 0. With each SFP ont eh same scale, homozygous Cvi genotypes = 0.5, heterozygous = 0, and Ler = -0.5. The allele frequency of any single SFP is noisy however an accurate estimate can be made by considering multiple SFPs along a region. We were interested in deviations from equal proportions of Cvi and Ler genotypes in a pool, an allele frequency of 0 on our scale. To identify these regions, the genotype of the Ler pool is subtracted from the Cvi pool. The resulting vector of allele frequency differences for each chromosome is then smoothed by loess. ).  Analysis scripts were adapted as follows. Since the parental accessions were Ler and Cvi and not Col, which is the basis of the targets located on the ATH1 Affymetrix Genechips®, two-tailed modified t-tests were performed instead of one-tailed. To minimize the possibility that identified SFPs represent duplications between Cvi and Ler accessions, potential SFP duplications were mapped using two-tailed t-test on previously published microarray data for Col/Ler (1382 duplications) and Col/Cvi (754 duplications) at the threshold used for mapping SFPs in Cvi/Ler accessions. Of these duplications 1937 were unique and 1054 SFP markers matched in the Cvi/Ler population and were thus removed from further analysis leaving a total of 26638 SFP markers for bulk segregant analysis.
